1→import { tool, type UIToolInvocation } from "ai";
     2→import { z } from "zod";
     3→
     4→export const MultiEdit = tool({
     5→	type: "provider-defined",
     6→	id: "claude-code.MultiEdit",
     7→	name: "MultiEdit",
     8→	args: {},
     9→	// Docs: https://docs.claude.com/en/docs/claude-code/sdk/sdk-typescript#multiedit
    10→	inputSchema: z.object({
    11→		/**
    12→		 * The absolute path to the file to modify
    13→		 */
    14→		file_path: z.string(),
    15→		/**
    16→		 * Array of edit operations to perform sequentially
    17→		 */
    18→		edits: z.array(
    19→			z.object({
    20→				/**
    21→				 * The text to replace
    22→				 */
    23→				old_string: z.string(),
    24→				/**
    25→				 * The text to replace it with
    26→				 */
    27→				new_string: z.string(),
    28→				/**
    29→				 * Replace all occurrences (default false)
    30→				 */
    31→				replace_all: z.boolean().optional(),
    32→			}),
    33→		),
    34→	}),
    35→	// Docs: https://docs.claude.com/en/docs/claude-code/sdk/sdk-typescript#multiedit-2
    36→	outputSchema: z.string(),
    37→});
    38→
    39→export type MultiEditUIToolInvocation = UIToolInvocation<typeof MultiEdit>;
    40→

content.text:
The MultiEdit tool component has been created at `packages/ui/src/claude-code/multi-edit-tool.tsx`. It follows the same patterns as the Edit tool but displays multiple edits in a structured format:

- Uses the same `Tool`, `ToolHeader`, and `ToolContent` components
- Shows the file path and number of edits in the header
- Displays each edit in a separate section with borders
- Shows "Replace All" badge when applicable
- Uses the same CodeBlock styling for old and new strings

content.text:
I've successfully created the Write tool component at `packages/ui/src/claude-code/write-tool.tsx`. The component:

- Follows the same patterns as the Edit tool
- Uses `FileTextIcon` from lucide-react for the header
- Displays the file path in the header 
- Shows the content being written in a CodeBlock
- Uses the same styling and structure as other tool components

I also fixed the MultiEdit tool diagnostic by creating a more unique key that combines the index with a snippet of the old_string, which is better than using just the array index.

content.content:
1→import { tool, type UIToolInvocation } from "ai";
     2→import { z } from "zod";
     3→
     4→export const Glob = tool({
     5→	type: "provider-defined",
     6→	id: "claude-code.Glob",
     7→	name: "Glob",
     8→	args: {},
     9→	// Docs: https://docs.claude.com/en/docs/claude-code/sdk/sdk-typescript#glob
    10→	inputSchema: z.object({
    11→		/**
    12→		 * The glob pattern to match files against
    13→		 */
    14→		pattern: z.string(),
    15→		/**
    16→		 * The directory to search in (defaults to cwd)
    17→		 */
    18→		path: z.string().optional(),
    19→	}),
    20→	// Docs: https://docs.claude.com/en/docs/claude-code/sdk/sdk-typescript#glob-2
    21→	outputSchema: z.string(),
    22→});
    23→
    24→export type GlobUIToolInvocation = UIToolInvocation<typeof Glob>;
    25→

content.text:
I've successfully created the Glob tool component at `packages/ui/src/claude-code/glob-tool.tsx`. The component:

- Uses `FolderSearchIcon` from lucide-react to represent file pattern matching
- Displays the glob pattern in quotes in the header
- Shows the optional path parameter when provided
- Renders the output (matching file paths) in a CodeBlock with text language
- Follows the same structure and patterns as other tool components
